ANSWER: Based on the diagnosis of port-wine stain with secondary vascular and inflammatory changes, I recommend a comprehensive treatment approach that combines careful observation, diagnostic evaluation, and appropriate follow-up. Initially, I suggest detailed dermoscopic examination and consideration of biopsy by a dermatologist to accurately distinguish between benign vascular lesions and potential amelanotic melanoma. If confirmed benign, management will focus on monitoring the lesion’s stability, with patient education on skin self-examination and sun protection. In case of suspicious features or confirmed malignancy, surgical excision or other definitive treatments will be pursued.
Initial management includes arranging specialized dermatology evaluation within two weeks, with clear instructions on observing for changes. Follow-up will be scheduled every 3-6 months to assess for lesion stability.
